thread.section_title: High School Sports, Prep Sports in Los Angeles, San Fernando Valley: Los Angeles Daily News
thread.title: Flintridge Sacred Heart avenges loss to Marymount
thread.title_full: Flintridge Sacred Heart avenges loss to Marymount

author: Jacob H. Pollon,
title: Flintridge Sacred Heart avenges loss to Marymount
text:
WESTWOOD >> The Flintridge Sacred Heart girls volleyball team exacted a bit of revenge Tuesday in a Mission League showdown against Marymount.
After dropping a four-set match back on Oct. 1, the Tologs (18-7, 4-2) returned the favor in eerily the same fashion.
The teams split the first two sets, but this time it was Flintridge Sacred Heart coming out on top in the final two sets for a 25-15, 19-25, 25-22, 26-24 win.
“We went into this match with nothing to lose,” Flintridge Sacred Heart’s Kayla Lund said. “We just went all out and put it all on the line. That’s what we had to do — not worry about anything else.”
Lund finished with a match-high 27 kills to lead the Tologs, who have won 11 of 13 matches dating back to Oct. 1.
“It came down to who got those rally points,” Lund said. “We knew it was going to be a tough match. We had to get those extra points, points on long rallies.”
Flintridge Sacred Heart showed grit and determination when it had to.
The Tologs won a tight set three and were trailing 20-15 in the fourth before mounting a tremendous comeback.
“We were good all-around and our middles really stepped up,” Lund said.
Flintridge Sacred Heart coach Ernest Banaag was more than pleased.
“I have to give credit to the girls,” Banaag said. “They not only followed the game plan, they didn’t relive the past. They were in control, had a good attitude and learned to win tonight. They stayed the course, didn’t get too up and didn’t get too down. We just tried to make it difficult for them. Our offense came alive and we made them have to work.”
Lund had plenty of help from her teammates in a solid, balanced effort.
Ellis DeJardin and Ali McCollum each had 13 kills.
DeJardin’s ace ended the match one play after Clare Lund put home a kill to break a 24-24 tie.
Clare Lund finished with 61 assists but was humble in victory.
“It’s easy to do that when you get great passes to set and hitters to put away balls,” she said. “It was awesome to see us play together, get some key kills, some key passes and keep our serves in.”
Flintridge Sacred Heart moved to within one game of Marymount in the league standings with three to play.
“We came together after the Harvard-Westlake loss and told each other it’s time to live up to our expectations,” Clare Lund said.
Advertisement
Kayla Lund added: “Our two league losses were a wake-up call. Our practice drills have changed, our mindset has changed. We come out on the court different now. We are definitely playing together.”
